individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Of government the properties to unfold Would seem in me t’ affect speech and discourse Since I am put to know that your own science Exceeds in that the lists of all advice My strength can give you Then no more remains But that to your sufficiency as your worth is able And let them work The nature of our people Our city’s institutions and the terms For common justice you’re as pregnant in As art and practice hath enrichèd any That we remember There is our commission He hands Escalus a paper From which we would not have you warp Call hither I say bid come before us Angelo An Attendant exits What figure of us think you he will bear For you must know we have with special soul Elected him our absence to supply Lent him our terror dressed him with our love And given his deputation all the organs Of our own power What think you of it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Angelo There is a kind of character in thy life That to th’ observer doth thy history Fully unfold Thyself and thy belongings Are not thine own so proper as to waste Thyself upon thy virtues they on thee Heaven doth with us as we with torches do Not light them for themselves for if our virtues Did not go forth of us ’twere all alike As if we had them not Spirits are not finely touched But to fine issues nor nature never lends The smallest scruple of her excellence But like a thrifty goddess she determines Herself the glory of a creditor Both thanks and use But I do bend my speech To one that can my part in him advertise Hold therefore Angelo In our remove be thou at full ourself Mortality and mercy in Vienna Live in thy tongue and heart Old Escalus Though first in question is thy secondary Take thy commission

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Thus stands it with me upon a true contract I got possession of Julietta’s bed You know the lady She is fast my wife Save that we do the denunciation lack Of outward order This we came not to Only for propagation of a dower Remaining in the coffer of her friends From whom we thought it meet to hide our love Till time had made them for us But it chances The stealth of our most mutual entertainment With character too gross is writ on Juliet

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Unhappily even so And the new deputy now for the Duke Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness Or whether that the body public be A horse whereon the governor doth ride Who newly in the seat that it may know He can command lets it straight feel the spur Whether the tyranny be in his place Or in his eminence that fills it up I stagger in but this new governor Awakes me all the enrollèd penalties Which have like unscoured armor hung by th’ wall So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round And none of them been worn and for a name Now puts the drowsy and neglected act Freshly on me ’Tis surely for a name

individual_exchanges.text: I have done so but he’s not to be found I prithee Lucio do me this kind service This day my sister should the cloister enter And there receive her approbation Acquaint her with the danger of my state Implore her in my voice that she make friends To the strict deputy bid herself assay him I have great hope in that for in her youth There is a prone and speechless dialect Such as move men Besides she hath prosperous art When she will play with reason and discourse And well she can persuade

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: No holy father throw away that thought Believe not that the dribbling dart of love Can pierce a complete bosom Why I desire thee To give me secret harbor hath a purpose More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends Of burning youth

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarThomas_MM
individual_exchanges.text: May your Grace speak of it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My holy sir none better knows than you How I have ever loved the life removed And held in idle price to haunt assemblies Where youth and cost witless bravery keeps I have delivered to Lord Angelo A man of stricture and firm abstinence My absolute power and place here in Vienna And he supposes me traveled to Poland For so I have strewed it in the common ear And so it is received Now pious sir You will demand of me why I do this

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarThomas_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Gladly my lord

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: We have strict statutes and most biting laws The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds Which for this fourteen years we have let slip Even like an o’ergrown lion in a cave That goes not out to prey Now as fond fathers Having bound up the threat’ning twigs of birch Only to stick it in their children’s sight For terror not to use in time the rod More mocked than feared so our decrees Dead to infliction to themselves are dead And liberty plucks justice by the nose The baby beats the nurse and quite athwart Goes all decorum

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarThomas_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It rested in your Grace To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased And it in you more dreadful would have seemed Than in Lord Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I do fear too dreadful Sith ’twas my fault to give the people scope ’Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall them For what I bid them do for we bid this be done When evil deeds have their permissive pass And not the punishment Therefore indeed my father I have on Angelo imposed the office Who may in th’ ambush of my name strike home And yet my nature never in the fight To do in slander And to behold his sway I will as ’twere a brother of your order Visit both prince and people Therefore I prithee Supply me with the habit and instruct me How I may formally in person bear Like a true friar More reasons for this action At our more leisure shall I render you Only this one Lord Angelo is precise Stands at a guard with envy scarce confesses That his blood flows or that his appetite Is more to bread than stone Hence shall we see If power change purpose what our seemers be

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And have you nuns no farther privileges

individual_exchanges.speaker: Nun_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Are not these large enough

individual_exchanges.text: Yes truly I speak not as desiring more But rather wishing a more strict restraint Upon the sisterhood the votarists of Saint Clare

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: This is the point The Duke is very strangely gone from hence Bore many gentlemen myself being one In hand and hope of action but we do learn By those that know the very nerves of state His givings-out were of an infinite distance From his true-meant design Upon his place And with full line of his authority Governs Lord Angelo a man whose blood Is very snow-broth one who never feels The wanton stings and motions of the sense But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge With profits of the mind study and fast He to give fear to use and liberty Which have for long run by the hideous law As mice by lions hath picked out an act Under whose heavy sense your brother’s life Falls into forfeit He arrests him on it And follows close the rigor of the statute To make him an example All hope is gone Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer To soften Angelo And that’s my pith of business ’Twixt you and your poor brother

individual_exchanges.text: Ay but yet Let us be keen and rather cut a little Than fall and bruise to death Alas this gentleman Whom I would save had a most noble father Let but your Honor know Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue That in the working of your own affections Had time cohered with place or place with wishing Or that the resolute acting of your blood Could have attained th’ effect of your own purpose Whether you had not sometime in your life Erred in this point which now you censure him And pulled the law upon you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis one thing to be tempted Escalus Another thing to fall I not deny The jury passing on the prisoner’s life May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two Guiltier than him they try What’s open made to justice That justice seizes What knows the laws That thieves do pass on thieves ’Tis very pregnant The jewel that we find we stoop and take ’t Because we see it but what we do not see We tread upon and never think of it You may not so extenuate his offense For I have had such faults but rather tell me When I that censure him do so offend Let mine own judgment pattern out my death And nothing come in partial Sir he must die

individual_exchanges.text: One Isabel a sister desires access to you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Teach her the way Servant exits O heavens Why does my blood thus muster to my heart Making both it unable for itself And dispossessing all my other parts Of necessary fitness So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons Come all to help him and so stop the air By which he should revive And even so The general subject to a well-wished king Quit their own part and in obsequious fondness Crowd to his presence where their untaught love Must needs appear offense Enter Isabella How now fair maid

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I am come to know your pleasure

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: That you might know it would much better please me Than to demand what ’tis Your brother cannot live

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Even so Heaven keep your Honor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yet may he live a while And it may be As long as you or I Yet he must die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Under your sentence

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yea

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: When I beseech you That in his reprieve Longer or shorter he may be so fitted That his soul sicken not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ha Fie these filthy vices It were as good To pardon him that hath from nature stolen A man already made as to remit Their saucy sweetness that do coin God’s image In stamps that are forbid ’Tis all as easy Falsely to take away a life true made As to put metal in restrainèd means To make a false one

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis set down so in heaven but not in Earth

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Say you so Then I shall pose you quickly Which had you rather that the most just law Now took your brother’s life or to redeem him Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness As she that he hath stained

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir believe this I had rather give my body than my soul

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I talk not of your soul Our compelled sins Stand more for number than for accompt

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: How say you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Nay I’ll not warrant that for I can speak Against the thing I say Answer to this I now the voice of the recorded law Pronounce a sentence on your brother’s life Might there not be a charity in sin To save this brother’s life

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Please you to do ’t I’ll take it as a peril to my soul It is no sin at all but charity

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Pleased you to do ’t at peril of your soul Were equal poise of sin and charity

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: That I do beg his life if it be sin Heaven let me bear it You granting of my suit If that be sin I’ll make it my morn prayer To have it added to the faults of mine And nothing of your answer

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Nay but hear me Your sense pursues not mine Either you are ignorant Or seem so crafty and that’s not good

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Let me be ignorant and in nothing good But graciously to know I am no better

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright When it doth tax itself as these black masks Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder Than beauty could displayed But mark me To be receivèd plain I’ll speak more gross Your brother is to die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: So

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And his offense is so as it appears Accountant to the law upon that pain

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: True

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Admit no other way to save his life As I subscribe not that nor any other But in the loss of question that you his sister Finding yourself desired of such a person Whose credit with the judge or own great place Could fetch your brother from the manacles Of the all-binding law and that there were No earthly mean to save him but that either You must lay down the treasures of your body To this supposed or else to let him suffer What would you do

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: As much for my poor brother as myself That is were I under the terms of death Th’ impression of keen whips I’d wear as rubies And strip myself to death as to a bed That longing have been sick for ere I’d yield My body up to shame

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Then must your brother die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And ’twere the cheaper way Better it were a brother died at once Than that a sister by redeeming him Should die forever

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence That you have slandered so

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ignomy in ransom and free pardon Are of two houses Lawful mercy Is nothing kin to foul redemption

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You seemed of late to make the law a tyrant And rather proved the sliding of your brother A merriment than a vice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O pardon me my lord It oft falls out To have what we would have we speak not what we mean I something do excuse the thing I hate For his advantage that I dearly love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: We are all frail

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Else let my brother die If not a fedary but only he Owe and succeed thy weakness

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Nay women are frail too

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ay as the glasses where they view themselves Which are as easy broke as they make forms Women help heaven men their creation mar In profiting by them Nay call us ten times frail For we are soft as our complexions are And credulous to false prints

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I think it well And from this testimony of your own sex Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger Than faults may shake our frames let me be bold I do arrest your words Be that you are That is a woman If you be more you’re none If you be one as you are well expressed By all external warrants show it now By putting on the destined livery

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I have no tongue but one Gentle my lord Let me entreat you speak the former language

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Plainly conceive I love you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My brother did love Juliet And you tell me that he shall die for ’t

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He shall not Isabel if you give me love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I know your virtue hath a license in ’t Which seems a little fouler than it is To pluck on others

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Believe me on mine honor My words express my purpose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ha Little honor to be much believed And most pernicious purpose Seeming seeming I will proclaim thee Angelo look for ’t Sign me a present pardon for my brother Or with an outstretched throat I’ll tell the world aloud What man thou art

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Who will believe thee Isabel My unsoiled name th’ austereness of my life My vouch against you and my place i’ th’ state Will so your accusation overweigh That you shall stifle in your own report And smell of calumny I have begun And now I give my sensual race the rein Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes That banish what they sue for Redeem thy brother By yielding up thy body to my will Or else he must not only die the death But thy unkindness shall his death draw out To ling’ring sufferance Answer me tomorrow Or by the affection that now guides me most I’ll prove a tyrant to him As for you Say what you can my false o’erweighs your true

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: To whom should I complain Did I tell this Who would believe me O perilous mouths That bear in them one and the selfsame tongue Either of condemnation or approof Bidding the law make curtsy to their will Hooking both right and wrong to th’ appetite To follow as it draws I’ll to my brother Though he hath fall’n by prompture of the blood Yet hath he in him such a mind of honor That had he twenty heads to tender down On twenty bloody blocks he’d yield them up Before his sister should her body stoop To such abhorred pollution Then Isabel live chaste and brother die More than our brother is our chastity I’ll tell him yet of Angelo’s request And fit his mind to death for his soul’s rest

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The miserable have no other medicine But only hope I have hope to live and am prepared to die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The miserable have no other medicine But only hope I have hope to live and am prepared to die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Be absolute for death Either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter Reason thus with life If I do lose thee I do lose a thing That none but fools would keep A breath thou art Servile to all the skyey influences That doth this habitation where thou keep’st Hourly afflict Merely thou art death’s fool For him thou labor’st by thy flight to shun And yet runn’st toward him still Thou art not noble For all th’ accommodations that thou bear’st Are nursed by baseness Thou ’rt by no means valiant For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork Of a poor worm Thy best of rest is sleep And that thou oft provok’st yet grossly fear’st Thy death which is no more Thou art not thyself For thou exists on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust Happy thou art not For what thou hast not still thou striv’st to get And what thou hast forget’st Thou art not certain For thy complexion shifts to strange effects After the moon If thou art rich thou ’rt poor For like an ass whose back with ingots bows Thou bear’st thy heavy riches but a journey And death unloads thee Friend hast thou none For thine own bowels which do call thee sire The mere effusion of thy proper loins Do curse the gout serpigo and the rheum For ending thee no sooner Thou hast nor youth nor age But as it were an after-dinner’s sleep Dreaming on both for all thy blessèd youth Becomes as agèd and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld and when thou art old and rich Thou hast neither heat affection limb nor beauty To make thy riches pleasant What’s yet in this That bears the name of life Yet in this life Lie hid more thousand deaths yet death we fear That makes these odds all even

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Be absolute for death Either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter Reason thus with life If I do lose thee I do lose a thing That none but fools would keep A breath thou art Servile to all the skyey influences That doth this habitation where thou keep’st Hourly afflict Merely thou art death’s fool For him thou labor’st by thy flight to shun And yet runn’st toward him still Thou art not noble For all th’ accommodations that thou bear’st Are nursed by baseness Thou ’rt by no means valiant For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork Of a poor worm Thy best of rest is sleep And that thou oft provok’st yet grossly fear’st Thy death which is no more Thou art not thyself For thou exists on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust Happy thou art not For what thou hast not still thou striv’st to get And what thou hast forget’st Thou art not certain For thy complexion shifts to strange effects After the moon If thou art rich thou ’rt poor For like an ass whose back with ingots bows Thou bear’st thy heavy riches but a journey And death unloads thee Friend hast thou none For thine own bowels which do call thee sire The mere effusion of thy proper loins Do curse the gout serpigo and the rheum For ending thee no sooner Thou hast nor youth nor age But as it were an after-dinner’s sleep Dreaming on both for all thy blessèd youth Becomes as agèd and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld and when thou art old and rich Thou hast neither heat affection limb nor beauty To make thy riches pleasant What’s yet in this That bears the name of life Yet in this life Lie hid more thousand deaths yet death we fear That makes these odds all even

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I humbly thank you To sue to live I find I seek to die And seeking death find life Let it come on

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I humbly thank you To sue to live I find I seek to die And seeking death find life Let it come on

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What ho Peace here grace and good company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What ho Peace here grace and good company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What ho Peace here grace and good company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Who’s there Come in The wish deserves a welcome

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Who’s there Come in The wish deserves a welcome

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Dear sir ere long I’ll visit you again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Dear sir ere long I’ll visit you again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Most holy sir I thank you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Most holy sir I thank you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My business is a word or two with Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My business is a word or two with Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My business is a word or two with Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And very welcome Look signior here’s your sister

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And very welcome Look signior here’s your sister

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And very welcome Look signior here’s your sister

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Provost a word with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Provost a word with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Provost a word with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: As many as you please

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: As many as you please

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: As many as you please

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Bring me to hear them speak where I may be concealed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Bring me to hear them speak where I may be concealed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Bring me to hear them speak where I may be concealed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Now sister what’s the comfort

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Why As all comforts are most good most good indeed Lord Angelo having affairs to heaven Intends you for his swift ambassador Where you shall be an everlasting leiger Therefore your best appointment make with speed Tomorrow you set on

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Is there no remedy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: None but such remedy as to save a head To cleave a heart in twain

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: But is there any

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yes brother you may live There is a devilish mercy in the judge If you’ll implore it that will free your life But fetter you till death

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Perpetual durance

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ay just perpetual durance a restraint Though all the world’s vastidity you had To a determined scope

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: But in what nature

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In such a one as you consenting to ’t Would bark your honor from that trunk you bear And leave you naked

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Let me know the point

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O I do fear thee Claudio and I quake Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain And six or seven winters more respect Than a perpetual honor Dar’st thou die The sense of death is most in apprehension And the poor beetle that we tread upon In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great As when a giant dies

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Why give you me this shame Think you I can a resolution fetch From flowery tenderness If I must die I will encounter darkness as a bride And hug it in mine arms

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: There spake my brother There my father’s grave Did utter forth a voice Yes thou must die Thou art too noble to conserve a life In base appliances This outward-sainted deputy Whose settled visage and deliberate word Nips youth i’ th’ head and follies doth enew As falcon doth the fowl is yet a devil His filth within being cast he would appear A pond as deep as hell

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The prenzie Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O ’tis the cunning livery of hell The damned’st body to invest and cover In prenzie guards Dost thou think Claudio If I would yield him my virginity Thou mightst be freed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O heavens it cannot be

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yes he would give ’t thee from this rank offense So to offend him still This night’s the time That I should do what I abhor to name Or else thou diest tomorrow

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Thou shalt not do ’t

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O were it but my life I’d throw it down for your deliverance As frankly as a pin

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Thanks dear Isabel

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Be ready Claudio for your death tomorrow

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yes Has he affections in him That thus can make him bite the law by th’ nose When he would force it Sure it is no sin Or of the deadly seven it is the least

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Which is the least

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: If it were damnable he being so wise Why would he for the momentary trick Be perdurably fined O Isabel

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What says my brother

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Death is a fearful thing

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And shamèd life a hateful

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ay but to die and go we know not where To lie in cold obstruction and to rot This sensible warm motion to become A kneaded clod and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods or to reside In thrilling region of thick-ribbèd ice To be imprisoned in the viewless winds And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling ’tis too horrible The weariest and most loathèd worldly life That age ache penury and imprisonment Can lay on nature is a paradise To what we fear of death

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Alas alas

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sweet sister let me live What sin you do to save a brother’s life Nature dispenses with the deed so far That it becomes a virtue

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O you beast O faithless coward O dishonest wretch Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice Is ’t not a kind of incest to take life From thine own sister’s shame What should I think Heaven shield my mother played my father fair For such a warpèd slip of wilderness Ne’er issued from his blood Take my defiance Die perish Might but my bending down Reprieve thee from thy fate it should proceed I’ll pray a thousand prayers for thy death No word to save thee

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Nay hear me Isabel

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O fie fie fie Thy sin’s not accidental but a trade Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd ’Tis best that thou diest quickly

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O hear me Isabella

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Vouchsafe a word young sister but one word

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Vouchsafe a word young sister but one word

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What is your will

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What is your will

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Might you dispense with your leisure I would by and by have some speech with you The satisfaction I would require is likewise your own benefit

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Might you dispense with your leisure I would by and by have some speech with you The satisfaction I would require is likewise your own benefit

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I have no superfluous leisure My stay must be stolen out of other affairs but I will attend you awhile

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I have no superfluous leisure My stay must be stolen out of other affairs but I will attend you awhile

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Son I have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister Angelo had never the purpose to corrupt her only he hath made an assay of her virtue to practice his judgment with the disposition of natures She having the truth of honor in her hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to receive I am confessor to Angelo and I know this to be true Therefore prepare yourself to death Do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible Tomorrow you must die Go to your knees and make ready

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Son I have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister Angelo had never the purpose to corrupt her only he hath made an assay of her virtue to practice his judgment with the disposition of natures She having the truth of honor in her hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to receive I am confessor to Angelo and I know this to be true Therefore prepare yourself to death Do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible Tomorrow you must die Go to your knees and make ready

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Let me ask my sister pardon I am so out of love with life that I will sue to be rid of it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Claudio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Let me ask my sister pardon I am so out of love with life that I will sue to be rid of it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Hold you there Farewell Provost a word with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Hold you there Farewell Provost a word with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What’s your will father

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What’s your will father

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What’s your will father

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: That now you are come you will be gone Leave me awhile with the maid My mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: That now you are come you will be gone Leave me awhile with the maid My mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: That now you are come you will be gone Leave me awhile with the maid My mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In good time

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In good time

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In good time

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good The goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness but grace being the soul of your complexion shall keep the body of it ever fair The assault that Angelo hath made to you fortune hath conveyed to my understanding and but that frailty hath examples for his falling I should wonder at Angelo How will you do to content this substitute and to save your brother

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I am now going to resolve him I had rather my brother die by the law than my son should be unlawfully born But O how much is the good duke deceived in Angelo If ever he return and I can speak to him I will open my lips in vain or discover his government

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: That shall not be much amiss Yet as the matter now stands he will avoid your accusation he made trial of you only Therefore fasten your ear on my advisings To the love I have in doing good a remedy presents itself I do make myself believe that you may most uprighteously do a poor wronged lady a merited benefit redeem your brother from the angry law do no stain to your own gracious person and much please the absent duke if peradventure he shall ever return to have hearing of this business

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Let me hear you speak farther I have spirit to do anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Virtue is bold and goodness never fearful Have you not heard speak of Mariana the sister of Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I have heard of the lady and good words went with her name

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: She should this Angelo have married was affianced to her oath and the nuptial appointed Between which time of the contract and limit of the solemnity her brother Frederick was wracked at sea having in that perished vessel the dowry of his sister But mark how heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman There she lost a noble and renowned brother in his love toward her ever most kind and natural with him the portion and sinew of her fortune her marriage dowry with both her combinate husband this well-seeming Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Can this be so Did Angelo so leave her

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Left her in her tears and dried not one of them with his comfort swallowed his vows whole pretending in her discoveries of dishonor in few bestowed her on her own lamentation which she yet wears for his sake and he a marble to her tears is washed with them but relents not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid from the world What corruption in this life that it will let this man live But how out of this can she avail

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It is a rupture that you may easily heal and the cure of it not only saves your brother but keeps you from dishonor in doing it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Show me how good father

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her first affection His unjust unkindness that in all reason should have quenched her love hath like an impediment in the current made it more violent and unruly Go you to Angelo answer his requiring with a plausible obedience agree with his demands to the point Only refer yourself to this advantage first that your stay with him may not be long that the time may have all shadow and silence in it and the place answer to convenience This being granted in course and now follows all we shall advise this wronged maid to stead up your appointment go in your place If the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter it may compel him to her recompense and here by this is your brother saved your honor untainted the poor Mariana advantaged and the corrupt deputy scaled The maid will I frame and make fit for his attempt If you think well to carry this as you may the doubleness of the benefit defends the deceit from reproof What think you of it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The image of it gives me content already and I trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It lies much in your holding up Haste you speedily to Angelo If for this night he entreat you to his bed give him promise of satisfaction I will presently to Saint Luke’s There at the moated grange resides this dejected Mariana At that place call upon me and dispatch with Angelo that it may be quickly

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I thank you for this comfort Fare you well good father

individual_exchanges.text: Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia other some he is in Rome But where is he think you

individual_exchanges.text: I know not where but wheresoever I wish him well

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from the state and usurp the beggary he was never born to Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence He puts transgression to ’t

individual_exchanges.text: He does well in ’t

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in him Something too crabbed that way friar

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It is too general a vice and severity must cure it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yes in good sooth the vice is of a great kindred it is well allied but it is impossible to extirp it quite friar till eating and drinking be put down They say this Angelo was not made by man and woman after this downright way of creation Is it true think you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: How should he be made then

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Some report a sea-maid spawned him some that he was begot between two stockfishes But it is certain that when he makes water his urine is congealed ice that I know to be true And he is a motion generative that’s infallible

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You are pleasant sir and speak apace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Why what a ruthless thing is this in him for the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a man Would the duke that is absent have done this Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a hundred bastards he would have paid for the nursing a thousand He had some feeling of the sport he knew the service and that instructed him to mercy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I never heard the absent duke much detected for women He was not inclined that way

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O sir you are deceived

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: ’Tis not possible

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Who not the Duke Yes your beggar of fifty and his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish The Duke had crotchets in him He would be drunk too that let me inform you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You do him wrong surely

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir I was an inward of his A shy fellow was the Duke and I believe I know the cause of his withdrawing

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What I prithee might be the cause

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: No pardon ’Tis a secret must be locked within the teeth and the lips But this I can let you understand the greater file of the subject held the Duke to be wise

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Wise Why no question but he was

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: A very superficial ignorant unweighing fellow

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Either this is envy in you folly or mistaking The very stream of his life and the business he hath helmed must upon a warranted need give him a better proclamation Let him be but testimonied in his own bringings-forth and he shall appear to the envious a scholar a statesman and a soldier Therefore you speak unskillfully Or if your knowledge be more it is much darkened in your malice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir I know him and I love him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Love talks with better knowledge and knowledge with dearer love

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Come sir I know what I know

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I can hardly believe that since you know not what you speak But if ever the Duke return as our prayers are he may let me desire you to make your answer before him If it be honest you have spoke you have courage to maintain it I am bound to call upon you and I pray you your name

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir my name is Lucio well known to the Duke

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He shall know you better sir if I may live to report you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I fear you not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O you hope the Duke will return no more or you imagine me too unhurtful an opposite But indeed I can do you little harm you’ll forswear this again

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I’ll be hanged first Thou art deceived in me friar But no more of this Canst thou tell if Claudio die tomorrow or no

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Why should he die sir

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Why For filling a bottle with a tundish I would the Duke we talk of were returned again This ungenitured agent will unpeople the province with continency Sparrows must not build in his house eaves because they are lecherous The Duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered He would never bring them to light Would he were returned Marry this Claudio is condemned for untrussing Farewell good friar I prithee pray for me The Duke I say to thee again would eat mutton on Fridays He’s now past it yet and I say to thee he would mouth with a beggar though she smelt brown bread and garlic Say that I said so Farewell

individual_exchanges.text: No might nor greatness in mortality Can censure scape Back-wounding calumny The whitest virtue strikes What king so strong Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue But who comes here

individual_exchanges.text: His friends still wrought reprieves for him and indeed his fact till now in the government of Lord Angelo came not to an undoubtful proof

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It is now apparent

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Most manifest and not denied by himself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Hath he borne himself penitently in prison How seems he to be touched

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but as a drunken sleep careless reckless and fearless of what’s past present or to come insensible of mortality and desperately mortal

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He wants advice

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He will hear none He hath evermore had the liberty of the prison give him leave to escape hence he would not Drunk many times a day if not many days entirely drunk We have very oft awaked him as if to carry him to execution and showed him a seeming warrant for it It hath not moved him at all

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: More of him anon There is written in your brow provost honesty and constancy if I read it not truly my ancient skill beguiles me But in the boldness of my cunning I will lay myself in hazard Claudio whom here you have warrant to execute is no greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hath sentenced him To make you understand this in a manifested effect I crave but four days’ respite for the which you are to do me both a present and a dangerous courtesy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Pray sir in what

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In the delaying death

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Alack how may I do it having the hour limited and an express command under penalty to deliver his head in the view of Angelo I may make my case as Claudio’s to cross this in the smallest

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: By the vow of mine order I warrant you if my instructions may be your guide Let this Barnardine be this morning executed and his head borne to Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Angelo hath seen them both and will discover the favor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O death’s a great disguiser and you may add to it Shave the head and tie the beard and say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared before his death You know the course is common If anything fall to you upon this more than thanks and good fortune by the saint whom I profess I will plead against it with my life

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Pardon me good father it is against my oath

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Were you sworn to the Duke or to the Deputy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: To him and to his substitutes

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You will think you have made no offense if the Duke avouch the justice of your dealing

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: But what likelihood is in that

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Not a resemblance but a certainty yet since I see you fearful that neither my coat integrity nor persuasion can with ease attempt you I will go further than I meant to pluck all fears out of you Look you sir here is the hand and seal of the Duke He shows the Provost a paper You know the character I doubt not and the signet is not strange to you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I know them both

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The contents of this is the return of the Duke you shall anon overread it at your pleasure where you shall find within these two days he will be here This is a thing that Angelo knows not for he this very day receives letters of strange tenor perchance of the Duke’s death perchance entering into some monastery but by chance nothing of what is writ Look th’ unfolding star calls up the shepherd Put not yourself into amazement how these things should be All difficulties are but easy when they are known Call your executioner and off with Barnardine’s head I will give him a present shrift and advise him for a better place Yet you are amazed but this shall absolutely resolve you He gives the Provost the paper Come away it is almost clear dawn

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I am as well acquainted here as I was in our house of profession One would think it were Mistress Overdone’s own house for here be many of her old customers First here’s young Master Rash He’s in for a commodity of brown paper and old ginger ninescore and seventeen pounds of which he made five marks ready money Marry then ginger was not much in request for the old women were all dead Then is there here one Master Caper at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer for some four suits of peach-colored satin which now peaches him a beggar Then have we here young Dizzy and young Master Deep-vow and Master Copper-spur and Master Starve-lackey the rapier-and-dagger man and young Drop-heir that killed lusty Pudding and Master Forth-light the tilter and brave Master Shoe-tie the great traveler and wild Half-can that stabbed Pots and I think forty more all great doers in our trade and are now for the Lord’s sake

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sirrah bring Barnardine hither

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Master Barnardine you must rise and be hanged Master Barnardine

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: What ho Barnardine

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: A pox o’ your throats Who makes that noise there What are you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: A pox o’ your throats Who makes that noise there What are you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Your friends sir the hangman You must be so good sir to rise and be put to death

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Away you rogue away I am sleepy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Away you rogue away I am sleepy

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Tell him he must awake and that quickly too

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Pray Master Barnardine awake till you are executed and sleep afterwards

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Go in to him and fetch him out

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He is coming sir he is coming I hear his straw rustle

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Is the axe upon the block sirrah

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Very ready sir

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: How now Abhorson What’s the news with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: How now Abhorson What’s the news with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Truly sir I would desire you to clap into your prayers for look you the warrant’s come

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Truly sir I would desire you to clap into your prayers for look you the warrant’s come

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You rogue I have been drinking all night I am not fitted for ’t

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You rogue I have been drinking all night I am not fitted for ’t

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O the better sir for he that drinks all night and is hanged betimes in the morning may sleep the sounder all the next day

individual_exchanges.speaker: Pompey_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O the better sir for he that drinks all night and is hanged betimes in the morning may sleep the sounder all the next day

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Look you sir here comes your ghostly father Do we jest now think you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Look you sir here comes your ghostly father Do we jest now think you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Abhorson_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Look you sir here comes your ghostly father Do we jest now think you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir induced by my charity and hearing how hastily you are to depart I am come to advise you comfort you and pray with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir induced by my charity and hearing how hastily you are to depart I am come to advise you comfort you and pray with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir induced by my charity and hearing how hastily you are to depart I am come to advise you comfort you and pray with you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Friar not I I have been drinking hard all night and I will have more time to prepare me or they shall beat out my brains with billets I will not consent to die this day that’s certain

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Friar not I I have been drinking hard all night and I will have more time to prepare me or they shall beat out my brains with billets I will not consent to die this day that’s certain

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Friar not I I have been drinking hard all night and I will have more time to prepare me or they shall beat out my brains with billets I will not consent to die this day that’s certain

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O sir you must And therefore I beseech you look forward on the journey you shall go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O sir you must And therefore I beseech you look forward on the journey you shall go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O sir you must And therefore I beseech you look forward on the journey you shall go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I swear I will not die today for any man’s persuasion

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I swear I will not die today for any man’s persuasion

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I swear I will not die today for any man’s persuasion

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: But hear you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: But hear you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: But hear you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Not a word If you have anything to say to me come to my ward for thence will not I today

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Not a word If you have anything to say to me come to my ward for thence will not I today

individual_exchanges.speaker: Barnardine_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Not a word If you have anything to say to me come to my ward for thence will not I today

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Unfit to live or die O gravel heart After him fellows bring him to the block

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Unfit to live or die O gravel heart After him fellows bring him to the block

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Now sir how do you find the prisoner

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: A creature unprepared unmeet for death And to transport him in the mind he is Were damnable

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Here in the prison father There died this morning of a cruel fever One Ragozine a most notorious pirate A man of Claudio’s years his beard and head Just of his color What if we do omit This reprobate till he were well inclined And satisfy the Deputy with the visage Of Ragozine more like to Claudio

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O ’tis an accident that heaven provides Dispatch it presently The hour draws on Prefixed by Angelo See this be done And sent according to command whiles I Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: This shall be done good father presently But Barnardine must die this afternoon And how shall we continue Claudio To save me from the danger that might come If he were known alive

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Let this be done Put them in secret holds both Barnardine and Claudio Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting To yonder generation you shall find Your safety manifested

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I am your free dependent

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Quick dispatch and send the head to Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Now will I write letters to Angelo The Provost he shall bear them whose contents Shall witness to him I am near at home And that by great injunctions I am bound To enter publicly Him I’ll desire To meet me at the consecrated fount A league below the city and from thence By cold gradation and well-balanced form We shall proceed with Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Here is the head I’ll carry it myself

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Convenient is it Make a swift return For I would commune with you of such things That want no ear but yours

individual_exchanges.speaker: Provost_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I’ll make all speed

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Peace ho be here

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The tongue of Isabel She’s come to know If yet her brother’s pardon be come hither But I will keep her ignorant of her good To make her heavenly comforts of despair When it is least expected

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ho by your leave

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Good morning to you fair and gracious daughter

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: The better given me by so holy a man Hath yet the Deputy sent my brother’s pardon

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He hath released him Isabel from the world His head is off and sent to Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Nay but it is not so

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It is no other Show your wisdom daughter in your close patience

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O I will to him and pluck out his eyes

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You shall not be admitted to his sight

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Unhappy Claudio wretched Isabel Injurious world most damnèd Angelo

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot Forbear it therefore give your cause to heaven Mark what I say which you shall find By every syllable a faithful verity The Duke comes home tomorrow nay dry your eyes One of our convent and his confessor Gives me this instance Already he hath carried Notice to Escalus and Angelo Who do prepare to meet him at the gates There to give up their power If you can pace your wisdom In that good path that I would wish it go And you shall have your bosom on this wretch Grace of the Duke revenges to your heart And general honor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I am directed by you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: This letter then to Friar Peter give ’Tis that he sent me of the Duke’s return Say by this token I desire his company At Mariana’s house tonight Her cause and yours I’ll perfect him withal and he shall bring you Before the Duke and to the head of Angelo Accuse him home and home For my poor self I am combinèd by a sacred vow And shall be absent Wend you with this letter He hands her the paper Command these fretting waters from your eyes With a light heart Trust not my holy order If I pervert your course Who’s here

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Good even friar where’s the Provost

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Good even friar where’s the Provost

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Not within sir

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Not within sir

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O pretty Isabella I am pale at mine heart to see thine eyes so red Thou must be patient I am fain to dine and sup with water and bran I dare not for my head fill my belly One fruitful meal would set me to ’t But they say the Duke will be here tomorrow By my troth Isabel I loved thy brother If the old fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home he had lived

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O pretty Isabella I am pale at mine heart to see thine eyes so red Thou must be patient I am fain to dine and sup with water and bran I dare not for my head fill my belly One fruitful meal would set me to ’t But they say the Duke will be here tomorrow By my troth Isabel I loved thy brother If the old fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home he had lived

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir the Duke is marvelous little beholding to your reports but the best is he lives not in them

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Friar thou knowest not the Duke so well as I do He’s a better woodman than thou tak’st him for

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Well you’ll answer this one day Fare you well

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Nay tarry I’ll go along with thee I can tell thee pretty tales of the Duke

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You have told me too many of him already sir if they be true if not true none were enough

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I was once before him for getting a wench with child

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Did you such a thing

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Yes marry did I but I was fain to forswear it They would else have married me to the rotten medlar

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Sir your company is fairer than honest Rest you well

individual_exchanges.speaker: Lucio_MM
individual_exchanges.text: By my troth I’ll go with thee to the lane’s end If bawdy talk offend you we’ll have very little of it Nay friar I am a kind of burr I shall stick

individual_exchanges.speaker: Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In most uneven and distracted manner His actions show much like to madness Pray heaven his wisdom be not tainted And why meet him at the gates and deliver our authorities there

individual_exchanges.speaker: Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I guess not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his entering that if any crave redress of injustice they should exhibit their petitions in the street

individual_exchanges.speaker: Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: He shows his reason for that to have a dispatch of complaints and to deliver us from devices hereafter which shall then have no power to stand against us

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Well I beseech you let it be proclaimed Betimes i’ th’ morn I’ll call you at your house Give notice to such men of sort and suit as are to meet him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I shall sir Fare you well

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Good night Escalus exits This deed unshapes me quite makes me unpregnant And dull to all proceedings A deflowered maid And by an eminent body that enforced The law against it But that her tender shame Will not proclaim against her maiden loss How might she tongue me Yet reason dares her no For my authority bears of a credent bulk That no particular scandal once can touch But it confounds the breather He should have lived Save that his riotous youth with dangerous sense Might in the times to come have ta’en revenge By so receiving a dishonored life With ransom of such shame Would yet he had lived Alack when once our grace we have forgot Nothing goes right We would and we would not

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: These letters at fit time deliver me The Provost knows our purpose and our plot The matter being afoot keep your instruction And hold you ever to our special drift Though sometimes you do blench from this to that As cause doth minister Go call at Flavius’ house And tell him where I stay Give the like notice To Valencius Rowland and to Crassus And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate But send me Flavius first

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarPeter_MM
individual_exchanges.text: It shall be speeded well

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I thank thee Varrius Thou hast made good haste Come we will walk There’s other of our friends Will greet us here anon My gentle Varrius

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: To speak so indirectly I am loath I would say the truth but to accuse him so That is your part yet I am advised to do it He says to veil full purpose

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mariana_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Be ruled by him

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Besides he tells me that if peradventure He speak against me on the adverse side I should not think it strange for ’tis a physic That’s bitter to sweet end

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mariana_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I would Friar Peter

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O peace the Friar is come

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O peace the Friar is come

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarPeter_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Come I have found you out a stand most fit Where you may have such vantage on the Duke He shall not pass you Twice have the trumpets sounded The generous and gravest citizens Have hent the gates and very near upon The Duke is entering Therefore hence away

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarPeter_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Come I have found you out a stand most fit Where you may have such vantage on the Duke He shall not pass you Twice have the trumpets sounded The generous and gravest citizens Have hent the gates and very near upon The Duke is entering Therefore hence away

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My very worthy cousin fairly met To Escalus Our old and faithful friend we are glad to see you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My very worthy cousin fairly met To Escalus Our old and faithful friend we are glad to see you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Happy return be to your royal Grace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Happy return be to your royal Grace

individual_exchanges.text: Happy return be to your royal Grace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM Escalus_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Happy return be to your royal Grace

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Many and hearty thankings to you both We have made inquiry of you and we hear Such goodness of your justice that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks Forerunning more requital

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Many and hearty thankings to you both We have made inquiry of you and we hear Such goodness of your justice that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks Forerunning more requital

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You make my bonds still greater

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You make my bonds still greater

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You make my bonds still greater

individual_exchanges.text: You make my bonds still greater

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You make my bonds still greater

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: You make my bonds still greater

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O your desert speaks loud and I should wrong it To lock it in the wards of covert bosom When it deserves with characters of brass A forted residence ’gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion Give me your hand And let the subject see to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favors that keep within Come Escalus You must walk by us on our other hand And good supporters are you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O your desert speaks loud and I should wrong it To lock it in the wards of covert bosom When it deserves with characters of brass A forted residence ’gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion Give me your hand And let the subject see to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favors that keep within Come Escalus You must walk by us on our other hand And good supporters are you

individual_exchanges.text: O your desert speaks loud and I should wrong it To lock it in the wards of covert bosom When it deserves with characters of brass A forted residence ’gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion Give me your hand And let the subject see to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favors that keep within Come Escalus You must walk by us on our other hand And good supporters are you

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: O prince I conjure thee as thou believest There is another comfort than this world That thou neglect me not with that opinion That I am touched with madness Make not impossible That which but seems unlike ’Tis not impossible But one the wicked’st caitiff on the ground May seem as shy as grave as just as absolute As Angelo Even so may Angelo In all his dressings caracts titles forms Be an archvillain Believe it royal prince If he be less he’s nothing but he’s more Had I more name for badness

individual_exchanges.text: O gracious duke Harp not on that nor do not banish reason For inequality but let your reason serve To make the truth appear where it seems hid And hide the false seems true

individual_exchanges.speaker: Isabella_MM
individual_exchanges.text: In brief to set the needless process by How I persuaded how I prayed and kneeled How he refelled me and how I replied For this was of much length the vile conclusion I now begin with grief and shame to utter He would not but by gift of my chaste body To his concupiscible intemperate lust Release my brother and after much debatement My sisterly remorse confutes mine honor And I did yield to him But the next morn betimes His purpose surfeiting he sends a warrant For my poor brother’s head

individual_exchanges.text: By heaven fond wretch thou know’st not what thou speak’st Or else thou art suborned against his honor In hateful practice First his integrity Stands without blemish next it imports no reason That with such vehemency he should pursue Faults proper to himself If he had so offended He would have weighed thy brother by himself And not have cut him off Someone hath set you on Confess the truth and say by whose advice Thou cam’st here to complain

individual_exchanges.text: And is this all Then O you blessèd ministers above Keep me in patience and with ripened time Unfold the evil which is here wrapped up In countenance Heaven shield your Grace from woe As I thus wronged hence unbelievèd go

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: I know you’d fain be gone An officer An Officer comes forward To prison with her Shall we thus permit A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall On him so near us This needs must be a practice Who knew of your intent and coming hither

individual_exchanges.text: Blessed be your royal Grace I have stood by my lord and I have heard Your royal ear abused First hath this woman Most wrongfully accused your substitute Who is as free from touch or soil with her As she from one ungot

individual_exchanges.speaker: FriarPeter_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Well he in time may come to clear himself But at this instant he is sick my lord Of a strange fever Upon his mere request Being come to knowledge that there was complaint Intended ’gainst Lord Angelo came I hither To speak as from his mouth what he doth know Is true and false and what he with his oath And all probation will make up full clear Whensoever he’s convented First for this woman To justify this worthy nobleman So vulgarly and personally accused Her shall you hear disprovèd to her eyes Till she herself confess it

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mariana_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My husband bids me Now I will unmask She removes her veil This is that face thou cruel Angelo Which once thou swor’st was worth the looking on This is the hand which with a vowed contract Was fast belocked in thine This is the body That took away the match from Isabel And did supply thee at thy garden house In her imagined person

individual_exchanges.speaker: Angelo_MM
individual_exchanges.text: My lord I must confess I know this woman And five years since there was some speech of marriage Betwixt myself and her which was broke off Partly for that her promisèd proportions Came short of composition but in chief For that her reputation was disvalued In levity Since which time of five years I never spake with her saw her nor heard from her Upon my faith and honor

individual_exchanges.speaker: Mariana_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Noble prince As there comes light from heaven and words from breath As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue I am affianced this man’s wife as strongly As words could make up vows And my good lord But Tuesday night last gone in ’s garden house He knew me as a wife As this is true Let me in safety raise me from my knees Or else forever be confixèd here A marble monument

individual_exchanges.text: I did but smile till now Now good my lord give me the scope of justice My patience here is touched I do perceive These poor informal women are no more But instruments of some more mightier member That sets them on Let me have way my lord To find this practice out

individual_exchanges.speaker: Duke_MM
individual_exchanges.text: Ay with my heart And punish them to your height of pleasure Thou foolish friar and thou pernicious woman Compact with her that’s gone think’st thou thy oaths Though they would swear down each particular saint Were testimonies against his worth and credit That’s sealed in approbation You Lord Escalus Sit with my cousin lend him your kind pains To find out this abuse whence ’tis derived The Duke rises Escalus is seated There is another friar that set them on Let him be sent for
